sub_title: Senior Optical Sensing Enginer, EUV Source Metrology
summary:
As a Senior Optical Sensing Engineer I am responsible for the design and development of the optical module - along with dedicated algorithms - that is the metrology cornerstone of the EUV Scanner: the machine producing microchips with EUV technology.

Specifically, my mission is to obtain a complete understanding of the system behavior in a real life environment. This is achieved by combining a rigorous data analysis through the creation of specific algorithms, together with an accurate physical description of the systems in question.

I'm fascinated by the challenge of solving complex problems to enable the creation of the latest generation of microchips. This is a an extremely fast paced and growing sector, therefore having the right "time to market" raises the bar for the challenges I face daily.

This involves a continuous and constant feedback with many teams and colleagues with different cultures and backgrounds. I value team work very much and I am dedicated to do my best to improve group results; I am able to adapt myself to different kind of situations and problems and find the best way to overcome obstacles.

My goal is to use my scientific expertise to solve challenges within the R&D department of a company operating in the field of optics or related topics.

profile_positions.description:
- Within the EUV business line, I Lead a team of 6 FTE tasked with developing physical and mathematical models to be implemented in our EUV Scanner: it is the latest tool for microchip development tool working with extreme ultraviolet light technology. 

- In my role, I'm responsible to define the team deliverables and the consequent planning to achieve them. I focus on customers and stakeholders requests and balance them with the team capabilities to fulfill them.

- I mitigate issues and risks by collaborating with other groups and departments to make sure our plans are synced.

- I collaborate with our external partners to help them meet our technical requests and specifications, as well as the expected delivery time..

- Troubleshooting and providing support during escalations (algorithm and/or hardware related) at customer machines (Taiwan, South Korea, United States) on issues related to system metrology.

- Training of junior colleagues on Matlab skillsets, algorithm development and sensor metrology.
profile_positions.title: Team Leader

profile_positions.description:
- Design and development of new sensor metrology, along with image processing algorithms, to contribute to the next generation of EUV machines. Specifically, my tasks are focused in the EUV Source, where a high power laser gets converted to ultraviolet light. As metrology expert, I give inputs on the key quantities to be measured and how that should be achieved, with the goal of describing the physics of our machines, and the laser beam in it, in the most representative way.

- Development of new algorithms and key performance metrics by combining and analyzing machine calibration reports, raw data, and logging files. This is combined with sensor physical insights and theoretical derivations with the ultimate goal of improving sensor accuracy and processing speed.

- Technical lead in infrared laser beam sensing and image processing.

- Troubleshooting and providing support during escalations (algorithm and/or hardware related) at customer machines (Taiwan, South Korea, United States) on issues related to system metrology.

- Training of junior colleagues on Matlab skillsets, algorithm development and sensor metrology.

profile_positions.description:
The project is in collaboration with the dutch multinational company ASML, world leader in lithography machines for the semiconductor industry.

Research topic "Nano-inspection for next-generation lithography".

• Rigorous simulation via COMSOL and Rigorous Coupled Wave Analysis (RCWA).
• Phase and amplitude laser beam shaping with Spatial Light Modulator (SLM).
• Data analysis via Matlab, Mathematica and C++.
• Study of different phase unwrapping methods.
• Characterization of an optical setup for interferometry and scatterometry measurements.
• Samples fabrication via Electron Beam Lithography and Reactive Ion Etching.
• Samples analysis via Atomic Force Microscopy (AFM) and Scanning Electron Microscope (SEM).
profile_positions.title: PhD student

profile_positions.description:
I supervised a french student who did a 10 months master thesis project in the Optics Research Group.

The thesis was quite experimental and it dealt with the amplitude and phase shaping of a laser beam with a Spatial Light Modulator (SLM). In particular, we investigated different possible modulation patter for biological applications, e.g. optical tweezers.
